claims_to_validate.claim_text: Complete procedure: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave
claims_to_validate.validation_hint: Preconditions: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and needs to be reflected as a salary deduction || Steps: Receive and approve unpaid leave request -> Determine the employee's leave policy type (calendar days or working days) -> Identify the total number of days in the policy for the month (e.g., 22 working days or 30 calendar days) -> Identify all public holidays falling in the month -> Subtract public holidays from the total working days to calculate actual working days -> Calculate daily pay using formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Actual Working Days -> System automatically generates and reflects the pay deduction on the payroll table || Expected: Procedure completes without blocking validation errors | System shows success confirmation (toast/banner) OR state persists after refresh

claims_to_validate.claim_text: Complete procedure: Configure Daily Wage Calculator
claims_to_validate.validation_hint: Preconditions: When setting up payroll system or updating daily wage calculation methodology to align with company policies or labor law requirements. || Steps: Navigate to Settings menu -> Select Payroll section -> Click on Daily Wage Calculation -> Select calculation base (calendar days, working days, or custom days) -> Choose salary components to include (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only) -> Apply configuration to impact salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction calculations || Expected: Procedure completes without blocking validation errors | System shows success confirmation (toast/banner) OR state persists after refresh

claims_to_validate.claim_text: Complete procedure: Update Salary Proration
claims_to_validate.validation_hint: Preconditions: When organization needs to change how employee salaries are prorated based on days worked, or when adjusting calculation methodology for payroll accuracy. || Steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation -> Select the required calculation basis (custom days, calendar days, or working days) -> Save changes -> If payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, reject those transactions before saving new proration settings -> Confirm new proration settings are applied to all active unpaid payroll amounts || Expected: Procedure completes without blocking validation errors | System shows success confirmation (toast/banner) OR state persists after refresh

claims_to_validate.claim_text: UI indicates: Changes to salary proration settings affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table immediately upon save. When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions have been submitted for one or multiple employees, Super admin must reject those transactions before saving new salary proration changes.
claims_to_validate.validation_hint: Preconditions: Login as an admin user || Steps: Navigate to the relevant settings/screen referenced by this rule -> Locate the referenced UI control/label || Expected: The UI matches the documented rule/constraint text

claims_to_validate.claim_text: System applies a global daily rate configuration that supersedes individual leave policy calculation methods, potentially causing incorrect salary deductions

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new.
When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes inconsistent between HR and Payroll modules, resulting in incorrect salary deductions.
System shows daily rate from payroll processing month instead of leave occurrence month, causing user confusion
System calculates service duration differently from manual calculations, specifically in handling partial years above 5 years of service and leap year day counting
The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using independent daily wage configurations with different divisors (30 vs 30.42 days), causing calculation discrepancies.

End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. When calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.
The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave. Greyed-out formulas in leave policy indicate this override is active.

Payroll system fails to prorate salary when employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. System correctly prorates for past departure dates but not for future dates.
Daily wage calculator configured with 'working days' setting causes monthly variations in leave salary accrual calculations, resulting in inconsistent cumulative totals across months
The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for leap years, resulting in inaccurate gratuity calculations.
System calculates leave salary using a fixed daily rate divisor that may not match user expectations about calendar days, potentially causing salary calculation differences

The system displays incorrect daily rate in remarks for February, showing 925.81 (based on 31 days) instead of 989.66 (based on 29 days), even though the actual deduction calculation is mathematically correct.
System potentially miscalculates service duration by not consistently accounting for February 29th in leap years, causing minor gratuity calculation discrepancies
Platform calculates 623 days instead of 622 days when computing gratuity, adding an extra day to service duration calculation
System calculates working days based on work week configuration, which can result in full month (31 days) calculation if all days are marked as working days
February Unpaid Leave Deduction in Leap Year
Daily wage calculations are sensitive to the number of calendar days in a month, with potential display inconsistencies for months with variable days (especially February in leap years).
Unpaid leave deductions depend on salary configuration timing. Deductions may be incorrect if salary config is created after leave request.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were calculated based on previous salary configuration instead of current one.
Detailed explanation of gratuity calculation methodology
Calculating service duration across a leap year with February 29th
Unclear rules for counting departure date as a working day and calculating service years by dividing total days by 365
Leave request created in different month from payroll processing
Daily rate calculated as (Basic + Allowances) / Working Days, excluding public holidays
Display daily rate matching leave occurrence month
Allow daily wage calculation using (Basic × 12 / 365) formula
Platform's leave salary calculation is rigidly tied to predefined policy configurations, preventing manual override of standard calculation method
Handling unpaid leave in service duration calculation
Handling of incomplete service years in gratuity calculation
System uses 366 as divisor for leap years when calculating partial service periods
The system uses different divisors (30 and 30.42 days) for leave salary and salary proration calculations, preventing automatic alignment.
Inconsistent daily wage calculation during leave periods
Consistent daily wage calculation across leave salary and salary proration
Reliable mechanism for recalculating unpaid leave deductions without generating duplicate entries
Deleting a leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions. Moving leave request status does not resolve deduction persistence.
Recalculating daily wage after leave request approval creates duplicate deductions
Precise pro-rated amount calculation for employee departures
Calculating pro-rated salary for employees leaving mid-month
Daily wage is calculated as (basic salary + allowances) / 30, applied consistently across all employee departures
Consistent daily wage formula across leave policy and payroll settings
Payroll daily wage calculator configuration supersedes leave policy formula for unpaid leave calculations
Implement precise salary proration for employees with future departure dates
Payroll processed before employee's future departure date
Salary proration only works accurately for departure dates in the past, not for future dates
Maintain stable daily wage calculations across months
Daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals
Correct leap year calculation for end of service gratuity
System defaults to 365 days per year, failing to recognize leap years with 366 days in gratuity calculations.
Employee service spanning a leap year (2024)
NVK Operations work week with all 7 days as working days
Daily wage proration is calculated based on work week configuration, with working days determined by which days are marked as working
Full month absence with non-standard daily wage calculation
Understand why unpaid leave deduction exceeds monthly salary
Daily wage is calculated as: (basic salary + allowance) / working days, where working days exclude weekends and public holidays
Public holidays added after leave request creation cause calculation discrepancies
Automatically recalculate salary deduction when public holidays change
Allow dynamic adjustment of daily wage divisor between 30 and 31 days
Leave request spanning partial month with different salary calculation basis
Understand EOS gratuity calculation logic and leave balance inclusion
Employee departing mid-month with incomplete leave accrual
Platform lacks flexible leave accrual handling for mid-month departures, defaulting to monthly accrual that does not prorate or include partial month leave balances
Automated salary calculation based on 26 working days per month

steps: Receive and approve unpaid leave request
Determine the employee's leave policy type (calendar days or working days)
Identify the total number of days in the policy for the month (e.g., 22 working days or 30 calendar days)
Identify all public holidays falling in the month

System automatically generates and reflects the pay deduction on the payroll table
